AI version â€œMiningâ€ system for AIGC: Take stable diffusion image generation model as a example

è‹±æ–‡æ¥è‡ªäºNotion æœºå™¨ç¿»è¯‘

ä»‹äºç°åœ¨AIGCæ¨¡å‹çš„å…´èµ·ï¼Œå¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬è¦ç”Ÿæˆä¸€å¼ å›¾ç‰‡ï¼Œä¸€äº›äººåœ¨è®¡ç®—æœºç®—åŠ›ä¸Šæ˜¯éå¸¸ç¼ºå¤±çš„ï¼Œè€Œå¦ä¸€äº›äººå´æ‹¥æœ‰éå¸¸å¤šçš„è®¡ç®—æœºç®—åŠ›ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼ŒAIåº”ç”¨ä¸­ï¼Œ70%å·¦å³çš„ç®—åŠ›éƒ½åº”ç”¨åœ¨äº†æ¨æ¼”ä¸­ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘åœ¨æƒ³ï¼Œæ˜¯å¦å¯ä»¥è®¾è®¡ä¸€ä¸ªç±»ä¼¼äºä»¥å¤ªå¸æŒ–çŸ¿ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç”¨æ•°å­—è´§å¸è´­ä¹°gasï¼Œè€Œè´­ä¹°gasçº¦ç­‰äºè´­ä¹°ç®—åŠ›å’Œå­˜å‚¨ç©ºé—´ï¼Œç„¶åæˆ‘ä»¬ä¾¿å¯ä»¥ç”¨gaséƒ¨ç½²æˆ‘ä»¬çš„AIæ™ºèƒ½åˆçº¦(Smart contract)ã€‚

With the rise of AIGC models, if we want to generate an image, some people are very lacking in computer computing power, while others have a lot of computer computing power. Moreover, in AI applications, about 70% of the computing power is applied in inference. So Iâ€™m wondering if we could design something similar to Ethereum mining. We can buy gas with cryptocurrency, and purchasing gas is approximately equivalent to buying computing power and storage space. Then we can use the gas to deploy our AI smart contracts.

ç”±äºè¿è¡Œåˆçº¦çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œæ¨¡å‹å¯èƒ½ä¼šè¢«æ‹†åˆ†åˆ°å„å°æœºå™¨ä¸­è¿è¡Œï¼Œè€Œå¯è¢«æ‹†åˆ†çš„æ¨¡å‹æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°å…´çš„ç ”ç©¶æ–¹å‘ï¼Œå¦‚ Forward-Forward Algorithmå’Œæˆ‘çš„DFF: Distributed Forward-Forward Algorithmè®ºæ–‡ã€‚ç›®å‰ç ”ç©¶çš„å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆå®Œå–„ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨è¿™é‡Œå°† stable diffusion modelä¸­çš„stepsä½œä¸ºè¢«åˆ†å‰²çš„å¯¹è±¡ã€‚å³ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªstepåˆ†å‰²åˆ°å„ä¸ªæœºå™¨ä¸­è¿è¡Œï¼Œå¦‚ä¸‹å›¾ï¼š

When running contracts, the model may be split into different machines for operation, and a model that can be split is a new research direction, such as the Forward-Forward Algorithm and my DFF: Distributed Forward-Forward Algorithm paper. The current research is not complete. Therefore, we will use the steps in the stable diffusion model as the split objects here. That is, we will split each step into different machines for operation, as shown in the figure below:

æƒ³åœ¨å®Œæˆè¿™å¥—ç³»ç»Ÿä¸»è¦å­˜åœ¨çš„é—®é¢˜æœ‰ï¼šï¼ˆä»¥åè¿˜ä¼šè¡¥å……ï¼‰

  1. å¦‚ä½•å°†é€šç”¨çš„é—®é¢˜åˆ‡å‰²æˆå°é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ
  2. å¦‚æœæ˜¯è¦è®­ç»ƒæ¨¡å‹ï¼Œè®­ç»ƒçš„æ—¶å€™æ•°æ®é›†åˆæ€ä¹ˆå¤„ç†ï¼Ÿ
  3. æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªNodeä¸­å¦‚ä½•è¯„ä»·æ˜¯å¦â€œæŒ–åˆ°â€äº†æˆ‘ä»¬å¸Œæœ›å¾—åˆ°çš„æ¨¡å‹ç»“æœï¼Ÿ
  4. å¦‚ä½•backpropagationï¼Ÿéœ€è¦backpropagationå—ï¼Ÿ
  5. å¦‚ä½•è§£å†³å¹¶å‘çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œå¦‚ä½•å°†æ¨¡å‹è®¾è®¡æˆå¹¶å‘æ¨æ¼”æˆ–è®­ç»ƒçš„ï¼Ÿ

The main problems that exist in completing this system are: (will be supplemented later)

  1. How to split general problems into smaller problems?
  2. If it is to train the model, how to handle the dataset during training?
  3. How to evaluate in each Node whether we have â€œminedâ€ the model results we hope to get?
  4. How to backpropagate? Is backpropagation needed?
  5. How to solve concurrency issues, and how to design the model for concurrent inference or training?

Open-vocabulary detection (OVOD) aims to generalize beyond the limited number of base classes labeled during the training phase. The goal is to detect novel classes defined by an unbounded (open) vocabulary at inference. [From link]

entry.title: ComfyUI-based Decentralized Content Generation Platform
entry.content:
1. ComfyUI

https://github.com/comfyanonymous/ComfyUI

åœ¨ä»‹ç»æˆ‘ä»¬å»ä¸­å¿ƒåŒ–çš„å†…å®¹ç”Ÿæˆå¹³å°ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å…ˆä»‹ç»ä¸€ä¸‹ComfyUIæ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œä»¥åŠä»–çš„ç†å¿µã€‚

ComfyUIâ€”The most powerful and modular diffusion model GUI and backend.

Before introducing our decentralized content generation platform, letâ€™s explain what ComfyUI is and its concept firstly.

ComfyUIâ€”The most powerful and modular diffusion model GUI and backend.

ä»å®ƒçš„ä»‹ç»å¯çŸ¥ï¼Œå®ƒæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè®©ä½ åœ¨stable diffusionç­‰å¤§é‡ç”Ÿæˆæ¨¡å‹ä¹‹é—´è®¾è®¡ä¸€æ¡æ»¡è¶³è‡ªå·±å·¥ä½œæµç¨‹éœ€è¦çš„æ¡†æ¶ã€‚æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹æˆ–è€…æ•°æ®æ“ä½œè¢«è®¾è®¡æˆäº†ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªnodeè¢«å…è®¸æ·»åŠ åˆ°ä½ ä»¬çš„å·¥ä½œæµä¸­ã€‚åœ¨è¿™é‡Œä½ å¯ä»¥ç»“åˆå„ç§æ¨¡å‹ä¹‹é—´çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼Œåœ¨æœ¬åœ°æ„å»ºè‡ªå·±ç‰¹è‰²çš„å†…å®¹ç”Ÿæˆå·¥ä½œæµã€‚åŒ…æ‹¬ä½†ä¸æ­¢text2img, img2img, impating, lora ç­‰å·¥ä½œæµã€‚

From its description, we can see that it is a framework that allows you to design a workflow that meets your needs among a large number of generative models such as stable diffusion. Each model or data operation is designed as a node that can be added to your workflow. Here you can combine the advantages of various models to build your own unique content generation workflow locally. This includes but is not limited to, text2img, img2img, inpainting, lora, and other workflows.

2. ComfyUIç—›ç‚¹ ComfyUI Pain Points

ä½†æ˜¯ï¼ŒComfyUiä¹Ÿå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªå·¨å¤§çš„ç—›ç‚¹ï¼Œé‚£å°±æ˜¯å¦‚æœä½ çš„å·¥ä½œæµä¸­è¿è¡Œäº†å¤§é‡çš„æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆä½ å°†éœ€è¦ä¸€å°è¶…é«˜æ€§èƒ½çš„ç”µè„‘æ¥åŒæ—¶è¿è¡Œè¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹ã€‚ç°å®æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ªäººå¯èƒ½è¿è¡Œå·¥ä½œæµä¸­çš„ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ–ä¸€äº›æ¨¡å‹ã€‚

However, ComfyUI also has a significant pain point. If your workflow runs a large number of models, you will need a high-performance computer to run these models on one local computer. The reality is that we as individuals may only be able to run one or a few models in the workflow in our PC.

3. å»ä¸­æ€§åŒ–çš„ComfyUI Decentralized ComfyUI

å¾—ç›ŠäºComfyUIçš„è®¾è®¡ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å…¶å®å¯ä»¥æŠŠå·¥ä½œæµä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªnodeçœ‹ä½œä¸€ä¸ªç‹¬ç«‹çš„ä¸ªä½“ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦åœ¨ä¸åŒçš„ç”µè„‘ä¸­åˆ›å»ºåŒæ ·çš„nodeå‘¢ï¼Ÿè¿™å®Œå…¨æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸­ç®—åŠ›çš„æµªè´¹ã€‚è¯•æƒ³ï¼Œæˆ‘çš„ç”µè„‘åªå¤Ÿæˆ‘è¿è¡ŒAæ¨¡å‹nodeï¼Œè€ŒSmithçš„ç”µè„‘å¤Ÿè¿è¡ŒBæ¨¡å‹nodeï¼ŒJoneåˆ™æ˜¯Cæ¨¡å‹nodeã€‚å¦‚æœæˆ‘çš„å·¥ä½œæµç¨‹éœ€è¦Aï¼ŒBï¼ŒCè¿™å››ä¸ªnode,é‚£æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æˆ‘å¯ä»¥å€Ÿç”¨Smithå’ŒJoneçš„ç®—åŠ›ä¾¿å¯è¿è¡Œï¼ŸåŒæ ·çš„Smithå’ŒJoneä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨æˆ‘çš„nodeè¿è¡Œä»–ä»¬æƒ³è¦çš„å·¥ä½œæµã€‚å”¯ä¸€éœ€è¦çš„å°±æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬nodeä½œä¸ºAPIæœåŠ¡æš´éœ²ç»™å„ä½ã€‚

Thanks to ComfyUIâ€™s design, we can actually treat each node in the workflow as an independent entity. So why should we create the same nodes on different computers? This is a complete waste of computing power. Imagine if my computer is only capable of running model node A, while Smithâ€™s computer can run model node B, and Jones can run model node C. If my workflow requires nodes A, B, and C, could I borrow the computing power from Smith and Jones to run it? Correspondingly, Smith and Jones could also use my node to run the workflows they want. The only thing needed for us is to expose our nodes as API services to everyone.

4. å¦‚ä½•æ„å»ºå»ä¸­æ€§åŒ–çš„ComfyUI How to Build a Decentralized ComfyUI

åœ¨æˆ‘çš„è®¡åˆ’ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åº”è¯¥æ˜¯é«˜åº¦ä¾èµ–ComfyUIæˆ–è€…å®ƒçš„nodeæ€æƒ³æ¥æ„å»ºæˆ‘ä»¬çš„å»ä¸­æ€§åŒ–å¹³å°ã€‚ä¸»è¦çš„è®¾è®¡æœ‰ä¸‹é¢å‡ ç‚¹:

In my plan, we should heavily rely on ComfyUI or its node concept to build our decentralized platform. The main designs include the following points:

1. ComfyUI API service node æœåŠ¡èŠ‚ç‚¹ ComfyUI API Service Node

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åŸºäºComfyUIçš„ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œç›´æ¥æ„å»ºAPI service node èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œå°è¯•å°†å…¶ä»–æ¨¡å‹çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹nodeè‡ªåŠ¨æ‰“åŒ…æˆä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªçš„API serviceæš´éœ²ç»™å…¶ä»–ä½¿ç”¨è€…ã€‚

Based on ComfyUIâ€™s features, we can directly build API service nodes, attempting to automatically package the other modelâ€™s nodes into individual API services exposed to other users.

2. Node management center èŠ‚ç‚¹ç®¡ç†ä¸­å¿ƒ Node Management Center

è™½ç„¶æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è‡ªå·±æ„å»ºå¾ˆå¤šComfyUI API service nodeèŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†äººæ˜¯ä¸å…·å¤‡å…¬æœ‰IPå°†è‡ªå·±çš„æœåŠ¡æš´éœ²åœ¨ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åº”è¯¥æ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹ç®¡ç†ä¸­å¿ƒï¼Œç®¡ç†æœåŠ¡èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„åŒæ—¶ï¼Œè½¬å‘å„ä¸ªç§æœ‰IPæœåŠ¡èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œæš´éœ²ç»™å…¶ä»–ç”¨æˆ·ã€‚è€Œä½¿ç”¨è€…ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡ç®¡ç†ä¸­å¿ƒä½¿ç”¨è‡ªå·±æƒ³è¦çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹æœåŠ¡ã€‚

Although we can build many ComfyUI API service nodes ourselves, most people do not have a public IP to expose their services. We should build a node management center that manages service nodes while forwarding various private IP service nodes, exposing them to other users. Users can also use the node services they want through the management center.

3. Security (use tokens, data transmission crypto, anonymous, and so on) å®‰å…¨(tokens, æ•°æ®ä¼ è¾“åŠ å¯†ï¼ŒåŒ¿ååŒ–ç­‰ç­‰) Security (use tokens, data transmission crypto, anonymous, and so on)

èŠ‚ç‚¹ç®¡ç†ä¸­å¿ƒæ„å»ºæˆåŠŸçš„åŒ–ï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥æˆ‘ä»¬å°±éœ€è¦åœ¨æœåŠ¡èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œç®¡ç†ä¸­å¿ƒï¼Œä½¿ç”¨è€…ä¹‹é—´æ„å»ºå®‰å…¨å¯é çš„é€šä¿¡æœåŠ¡ã€‚tokenè®¤è¯ï¼Œä¼ è¾“æ•°æ®åŠ ï¼ŒåŒ¿ååŒ–ç­‰éƒ½éœ€è¦æˆ‘ä»¬æä¾›æ”¯æŒã€‚

If the node management center is successfully built, we then need to build secure and reliable communication services between service nodes, management centers, and users. We need to provide support for token authentication, data transmission encryption, anonymization, and more.

4. Payment Strategy(cyber currency? Onlie payment? Credit cart?) æ”¯ä»˜ç­–ç•¥(åŠ å¯†è´§å¸ï¼Œ åœ¨çº¿æ”¯ä»˜ï¼Œ ä¿¡ç”¨å¡) Payment Strategy (cryptocurrency? Online payment? Credit card?)

ä¸ºäº†æ›´å¤§åŒ–çš„æ¨å¹¿æˆ‘ä»¬çš„å»ä¸­å¿ƒåŒ–èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œåˆ©ç›Šå½“ç„¶æ˜¯æœ€å¤§çš„æ¨æ‰‹ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„ä½¿ç”¨è€…æ”¯ä»˜ä¸€å®šçš„è´¹ç”¨ç»™èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æä¾›è€…ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶èŠ‚ç‚¹ç®¡ç†ä¸­å¿ƒä¹Ÿéœ€è¦ä¸€å®šçš„èµ„é‡‘æ”¯æŒæœåŠ¡å™¨å’Œç”µä¿¡æœåŠ¡çš„è´¹ç”¨ã€‚è¿™æ ·å­æ‰å¯ä»¥ä¿ƒè¿›æ•´ä¸ªç¤¾åŒºçš„æ­£å‘å‘å±•ã€‚

To maximize the promotion of our decentralized nodes, profit is certainly the biggest driver. We need node users to pay a certain fee to node providers, and the node management center also needs some funds to support server and telecommunication service costs. By this way, we can promote the positive development of the entire community.

5. Everyone can make money, and everyone can use large computing power services æ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡å®ƒæŒ£é’±ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªäººéƒ½å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨å¤§è®¡ç®—é‡çš„æœåŠ¡

è‡³æ­¤ï¼Œæ¯ä¸€ä¸ªäººéƒ½å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªå·±çš„ç”µè„‘æ­å»ºä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹æ¥è·å¾—æ”¶ç›Šï¼Œè€Œå¤§å®¶ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ä»»æ„çš„ä½¿ç”¨æœ€å¤§é‡çš„ç®—åŠ›ç”Ÿæˆè‡ªå·±æƒ³è¦çš„å†…å®¹ã€‚

Therefore, everyone can use their computer to set up a node to earn income, and everyone can use the maximum amount of computing power to generate the content they want.

5. å¦å¤– Moreover

å¦å¤–ï¼Œ è™½ç„¶æˆ‘ä»¬çš„å¹³å°æ˜¯åŸºäºComfyUIçš„æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘è®¤ä¸ºé€šè¿‡åˆç†çš„è®¾è®¡ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ä½†å¯ä»¥æŠŠè¿™ä¸ªå¹³å°ä½¿ç”¨åˆ°å†…å®¹ç”Ÿæˆå·¥ä½œæµä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åº”ç”¨åˆ°ä»»ä½•çš„AIæ¨¡å‹å·¥ä½œæµç®—åŠ›å…±äº«ä¸­ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åŠ›æ±‚æ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ªå…¨çƒAIç®—åŠ›å…±äº«å¹³å°ã€‚æˆ–è®¸ä»¥åè¿˜å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨è¿™ä¸ªå¹³å°è¿›è¡Œæ¨¡å‹çš„è®­ç»ƒå’Œæ•°æ®çš„æ”¶é›†ç­‰AIæ¨¡å‹çš„å‰ç½® ã€‚

In addition, although our platform is based on the concept of ComfyUI, I believe that through reasonable design, we can not only use this platform in content generation workflows, but we can also apply it to any AI model workflow computing power sharing. We strive to build a global AI computing power sharing platform. Perhaps in the future, we can also use this platform for model training and data collection, and other AI model prerequisites.

entry.title: Dynamic Neural Architecture(DNA)
entry.content:
Dynamic Neural Architecture(DNA)

Check out my project on GitHub

This is my little research project. I try to make a dynamic neural network with one layer for decentralized artificial intelligence(DAI) purpose. We can dynamic delete and create neural cell node. This idea is inspired by Hebbian theory. I am not sure is will work or not. Letâ€™s see!

Fire together wire together(Hebbian theory)

Let us assume that the persistence or repetition of a reverberatory activity (or â€œtraceâ€) tends to induce lasting cellular changes that add to its stability. â€¦ When an axon of cell A is near enough to excite a cell B and repeatedly or persistently takes part in firing it, some growth process or metabolic change takes place in one or both cells such that Aâ€™s efficiency, as one of the cells firing B, is increased.â€Š

â€“ From Hebbian theory

So, In my understanding, for a AI model neural, letâ€™s say the assumption of â€˜the persistence or repetition of a reverberatory activityâ€™ is the training process, the â€˜cellâ€™ is a neural structure int the model, â€˜When an axon of cell A is near enough to excite a cell B and repeatedly or persistently takes part in firing it, some growth process or metabolic change takes place in one or both cells such that Aâ€™s efficiency, as one of the cells firing B, is increased.â€™ means if neural A is activated, A will active(fire) neural B sequently.

How about to make a AI model base on this theory.

Before I design my model, I try to modify some rule in Hebbian theory. In Hebbian theory, cell A will be activated before B, then cell B will be activated by cell A. But, to make a parallel architecture for my future plan about my decentralized model. I am going to activate neural A and neral B. Because In my opinion, they will finally be activated for a same activity no matter the order.

Neural cell

So. In my idea, neural cell can be assumed as a weighted signal function minus a signal leaking[Hodgkinâ€“Huxley model].

I=CmdVmÂ dt+gK(Vmâˆ’VK)+gNa(Vmâˆ’VNa)+gl(Vmâˆ’Vl)I=C_m \frac{\mathrm{d} V_m}{\mathrm{~d} t}+g_K\left(V_m-V_K\right)+g_{N a}\left(V_m-V_{N a}\right)+g_l\left(V_m-V_l\right)I=Cmâ€‹Â dtdVmâ€‹â€‹+gKâ€‹(Vmâ€‹âˆ’VKâ€‹)+gNaâ€‹(Vmâ€‹âˆ’VNaâ€‹)+glâ€‹(Vmâ€‹âˆ’Vlâ€‹)

So, our neural cell can be simplified as ->

I=wVmâˆ’bI=wV_m-bI=wVmâ€‹âˆ’b

Yes, we can also replace thie simple function to a complicate function such as KAN model.

Can it work?

In common, the universal approximation theorem said a feed-forward network with a single hidden layer containing a finite number of neurons can approximate any continuous function. So, I think If we have enough neural cell, we can approximate any continuous function. Meanwhile, according the Kolmogorovâ€“Arnold representation theorem, every multivariate continuous function. can be represented as a superposition of the two-argument addition of continuous functions of one variable, we can make many simple many to one neural cells for each variable to represent any continuous function. [Mybe I was wrong.]

Create and delete neural cell

Yes, In my DNA system, the neural cells will be dynamically created or deleted.

Neural cell creation

Itâ€™s a simulation of â€˜fire together wire togetherâ€™. When the passthrough(we consider it as the weight $w_A$) is large in neural cell A, we need to create a branch neural cell B to enhance this signal. Once we crate the neural cell B. A and B will equally share the passthrough
which means the initialization will be:

wA=0.5Ã—wA;bA=bA;wB=0.5Ã—wB;bB=0;w_A = 0.5 \times w_A; \\ b_A = b_A; \\ w_B = 0.5 \times w_B; \\ b_B = 0; \\wAâ€‹=0.5Ã—wAâ€‹;bAâ€‹=bAâ€‹;wBâ€‹=0.5Ã—wBâ€‹;bBâ€‹=0;

Neural cell deletion

On the opposite, we also need to delete the very less passthroughâ€™s neural cell. We will just delete it and itâ€™s input and output relation with other neural cells.

But how

Well, I still struggle in how to make a rule to tell us when we need to create the neural cells and when we need to delete the neural cells.

My naive idea for now is just create the new branch for top 10% high passthrough neural cells and delete the bottom 10% low passthrough neural cells. [TBD, need rethinking]

But When(Extinction)

In my plan, the neural creation and deletion process(sounds like model pruning) will be implement when we finish n epochs train and the loss not going down for more k epochs(refer the early stopping method, but we do not stop). And I name this process as a new term â€“ â€˜extinctionâ€™. It will be like, we have gone through many epochs in the history of our earth, and in some epochs we have met the species mass extinctions and entered another thriving epoch. Our DNA model, also, after n epochs, the model undergoes a mass extinction of neural cells, then the model enters to a new thriving epoch.

Model structure initialization

Before we train DNA model, we need to confirm the initial model structure. The initial model will just be like a Fully connected layer but each node in this layer is the single valuable(signal) and each edge in this layer is neural cell.
Beside, each neural cellâ€™s trainable parameters $w$ and $b$ will be set to 1 and 0 respectively.

| |

TODO

  • Neural cell class
  • Model data structure to manage each neural cellâ€™s input and output
  • Neural cell creation function
  • Neural cell deletion function
  • Extinction function
  • Training example
  • Result evaluation

Next level

  • Forward-Forward algorithm or backpropagation-free method implement
  • Neural cell distributing on different device(DAI).
  • Self-perception, self-learning, and self-evolution.

entry.title: My rethink about Image generation and recognition
entry.content:
My rethink about Image generation and recognition

è‹±æ–‡éƒ¨åˆ†æ˜¯Notionæœºå™¨ç¿»è¯‘

äººç±»çš„å¤§è„‘æ˜¯å›¾åƒç”Ÿæˆæœ€åˆ©å®³çš„æœºå™¨ï¼Œè™½ç„¶æˆ‘ä»¬æ— æ³•ç›´æ¥å‘å¤–è¡¨ç°å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨å¤§è„‘ä¸­æƒ³è±¡å‡ºåƒå¥‡ç™¾æ€ªçš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œç”šè‡³åœ¨æˆ‘ä»¬çš„æ¢¦å¢ƒä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å®Œå…¨ç•…æ¸¸åœ¨è‡ªç”±æƒ³åƒçš„ä¸–ç•Œã€‚

The human brain is the most potent image generation machine. Although we canâ€™t express it directly, we can imagine all sorts of things in our brains. Even in our dreams, we can fully roam the world of free imagination.

ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬äººç±»æ˜¯å¦‚ä½•åœ¨è„‘ä¸­ç”Ÿæˆè¿™äº›ä¸œè¥¿çš„å‘¢ï¼Ÿåœ¨æˆ‘çš„ç†è§£ä¸­ï¼Œçºµä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥æƒ³è±¡å‡ºä»»ä½•ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªâ€œä»»ä½•ä¸œè¥¿â€ï¼Œå¾ˆéš¾è¶…è¿‡æˆ‘ä»¬çš„è®¤çŸ¥èŒƒå›´ï¼Œå³æˆ‘ä»¬å¸¸è¯´çš„æƒ³è±¡çš„å±€é™æ€§ã€‚

But how do we humans generate these things in our minds? In my understanding, though we can imagine anything, this â€œanythingâ€ is hard to exceed our cognitive range, which is often referred to as the limitation of imagination.

æˆ‘è®¤ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬æ‹¥æœ‰è¿™ç§å±€é™æ€§çš„åŸå› æ˜¯å› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦å…ˆè§‚å¯Ÿå·²æœ‰çš„äº‹ç‰©ï¼Œç„¶åæŠ½è±¡å’Œæ€è€ƒè¿™ä¸ªäº‹ç‰©çš„ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½æƒ³è±¡å‡ºåŸºäºè¿™ä¸ªäº‹ç‰©éƒ¨åˆ†ç‰¹å¾çš„å…¶ä»–äº‹ç‰©ã€‚

I believe we have this limitation because we need to observe existing things first, then abstract and think about the features of this thing, in order to imagine other things based on some features of this thing.

å› æ­¤ï¼Œå¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬éµä»äººç±»çš„æ€è€ƒæ–¹å¼åˆ›å»ºAIæ¨¡å‹çš„è¯ï¼Œæˆ‘å‡è®¾æ¨¡å‹åˆ†ä¸º3éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼š è§‚å¯Ÿï¼Œæƒ³è±¡å’Œæ€è€ƒã€‚

Therefore, if we create AI models following human thinking, I assume the model is divided into three parts: observation, imagination, and thinking.

ä¸Šå›¾å°±æ˜¯æˆ‘è®¤ä¸ºçš„ä¸€ä¸ªäººç±»å¤§è„‘çš„æ€ç»´é€»è¾‘ï¼Œæˆ–è€…è¯´æ˜¯ä¸€ç§å›¾åƒç”Ÿæˆçš„AIæ¨¡å‹çš„ç»“æ„ï¼Œè¯¥ç»“æ„æœ‰ç‚¹ç±»ä¼¼äºGAN(Generative Adversarial Network)æ¨¡å‹ã€‚

The above figure is what I think is the logic of human brain thinking, or the structure of an image generation AI model, which is somewhat similar to the GAN (Generative Adversarial Network) model.

Observation: æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä¼šè§‚å¯ŸçœŸå®å›¾ç‰‡ï¼Œå­¦ä¹ å¹¶æå–çœŸå®å›¾ç‰‡çš„éšè—ç‰¹å¾å€¼(Hidden Feature)ã€‚

Observation: We will observe real images, learn and extract the hidden features of real images.

Hidden Feature: è§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°çš„ç‰¹å¾å€¼ä¼šè¢«åº”ç”¨äºä¸¤ä¸ªæ–¹é¢ï¼Œä¸€æ–¹é¢æ˜¯ç”¨äºæ€è€ƒï¼Œä¸€æ–¹é¢æ˜¯ç”¨äºç”Ÿæˆå›¾ç‰‡ã€‚

Hidden Feature: The observed features will be applied in two ways, one for thinking and one for generating images.

Imagination: æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡æ€»ç»“åˆ°çš„Hidden Featureï¼Œå¯ä»¥è¯•å›¾ç”Ÿæˆä¸€å¼ æ–°çš„å›¾ç‰‡ï¼Œè¿™å¼ å›¾ç‰‡å’ŒåŸå›¾Real imageå¾ˆç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åˆä¸åŒï¼Œç›®çš„æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†ç”Ÿæˆä¸€å¼ èƒ½å¤Ÿè®©observationæå–åˆ°å’ŒReal imageç›¸ä¼¼ç‰¹å¾çš„å›¾ç‰‡ã€‚

Imagination: We can try to generate a new image through the summarized Hidden Feature. This image is similar to the original Real image, but different. The purpose is to generate an image that allows the observation to extract features similar to the Real image.

è®©æˆ‘ä»¬é‡æ–°å›åˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬äººç±»çš„æ€è€ƒå­¦ä¹ æ–¹å¼ä¸Šï¼Œå½“æˆ‘ä»¬ç‰™ç‰™å­¦è¯­æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå‡è®¾æˆ‘ä»¬è®¤è¯†â€œè½¦â€è¿™ä¸ªå•è¯ï¼Œè€å¸ˆä¼šç»™æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€å¼ è½¦çš„å›¾ç‰‡å¡ï¼Œç„¶ååå¤æ•™æˆ‘ä»¬è¿™ä¸ªä¸œè¥¿æ˜¯â€œè½¦â€ã€‚å½“æˆ‘ä»¬è®°ä½äº†è¿™å¼ å›¾ç‰‡å’Œä¸ä¹‹å¯¹åº”çš„å•è¯â€œè½¦â€ä¹‹åï¼Œç¥å¥‡çš„ä¸€å¹•å‘ç”Ÿäº†ï¼Œå³ä¾¿æˆ‘ä»¬çœ‹åˆ°äº†å¦ä¸€ä¸ªæ¨¡æ ·çš„è½¦ä¹‹åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»ç„¶èƒ½å¤Ÿâ€œçŒœâ€å‡ºè¿™æ˜¯è½¦ï¼è€Œè¿™æ ·ç¥å¥‡çš„èƒ½åŠ›æˆ‘è®¤ä¸ºå¯ä»¥å½’å› äºäººç±»æƒ³è±¡åŠ›ã€‚å› ä¸ºäººç±»åœ¨çœ‹åˆ°â€œè½¦â€çš„å›¾ç‰‡å¡ä¹‹åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸ä½†æ˜¯å­¦ä¹ äº†è½¦è¿™ä¸ªå›¾ç‰‡çš„ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œè¿˜å­¦ä¹ åˆ°äº†å¾ˆå¤šæŠ½è±¡çš„ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚è½¦æœ‰å››ä¸ªè½®å­ï¼Œæœ‰æ–¹å‘ç›˜ç­‰ç­‰ï¼Œå¹¶åŸºäºè¿™äº›æŠ½è±¡ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œå¤©é©¬è¡Œç©ºçš„æƒ³è±¡å‡ºäº†ä¸åŒçš„è½¦ï¼Œè€Œè¿™äº›æƒ³è±¡å‡ºæ¥çš„è½¦çš„æ ·å­ï¼Œä¹Ÿæœ‰åˆ©äºæˆ‘ä»¬å»è¯†åˆ«çœŸæ­£ç°å®ä¸­çš„è½¦ã€‚åœ¨é€šè¿‡Næ¬¡çš„å¯¹çœŸå®å›¾ç‰‡å’Œæƒ³è±¡å›¾ç‰‡çš„è§‚å¯Ÿä¹‹åï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¾¿èƒ½æ€è€ƒâ€œè½¦â€æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼ŒåŒæ˜¯ä¹Ÿå…·å¤‡äº†æƒ³è±¡è½¦çš„æ ·å­çš„æ¨¡å‹ã€‚å¦‚ä¸‹å›¾ï¼š

Letâ€™s return to our human thinking learning mode. When we were babbling, suppose we knew the word â€œcarâ€, the teacher would give us a picture card of a car, and repeatedly teach us that this thing is a â€œcarâ€. After we remembered this picture and the corresponding word â€œcarâ€, a miraculous scene happened. Even if we saw another car, we could still â€œguessâ€ it was a car! I attribute such magical ability to human imagination. Because after seeing the picture card of the â€œcarâ€, we not only learned the features of the car picture, but also learned many abstract features, such as the car has four wheels, a steering wheel, etc., and based on these abstract features, the sky-horse-like imagination came out. Different cars, and the appearance of these imagined cars, are also conducive to our identification of real cars in reality. After observing the real image and the imagined image for N times, we can think about what a â€œcarâ€ is, and also have a model that imagines the appearance of a car. As below:

Thinking: å¯¹äºç‰¹å¾çš„æ€è€ƒï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¤§è‡´éœ€è¦æ€è€ƒä¸¤ä¸ªæ–¹é¢çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼š

å›¾ç‰‡æ˜¯çœŸçš„è¿˜æ˜¯æƒ³è±¡å‡ºæ¥çš„ï¼Ÿ

ä¸€ä¸ªçœŸå‡äºŒåˆ†ç±»é—®é¢˜

å›¾åƒæè¿°çš„æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

ä¸€ä¸ªNLPæè¿°é—®é¢˜

Thinking: For thinking about features, we generally need to think about two aspects:

Is the picture real or imagined?

A true or false binary classification problem

What does the image describe?

An NLP description problem

å› æ­¤ï¼ŒåŸºäºè¿™ä¸€å¥—æ€ç»´é€»è¾‘ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æˆ–è®¸èƒ½å¤Ÿåˆ¶ä½œä¸€ä¸ªone-shotæˆ–è€…few-shotçš„æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œé€šè¿‡åå¤è§‚æµ‹(Observation)å’Œæƒ³è±¡(Imagination)åŒä¸€å¼ å›¾ç‰‡å¹¶å¯¹ä»–ä»¬è¿›è¡Œæ€è€ƒï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æˆ–è®¸èƒ½ç”Ÿä¸‰ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹ï¼šencoderï¼Œgenerator,å’Œthinkerä¸‰ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹ã€‚å¦‚ä¸‹å›¾ï¼š

Therefore, based on this set of thinking logic, we may be able to make a one-shot or few-shot model, through repeated Observation and Imagination of the same picture and thinking about them, we may be able to generate three models: encoder, generator, and thinker. As below:

Loss çš„è®¾è®¡ï¼Œå½“æˆ‘ä»¬è®¾è®¡losså‡½æ•°çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œä¸»è¦æ˜¯å¸§å¯¹åœ¨Thinkeræ¨¡å—çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼ŒRealå’ŒFakeå’Œå¯¹åº”çš„NLPæè¿°å‡å¯ä»¥è®¾è®¡å¯¹åº”çš„è·ç¦»losså‡½æ•°ã€‚

When designing the Loss function, it is mainly designed for the output of the Thinker module, both Real and Fake and the corresponding NLP description can design the corresponding distance loss function.

å¦å¤–ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜å¯ä»¥è®¾è®¡ä¸€ä¸ªpromptç¼–ç æ¨¡å—ï¼Œç»™æˆ‘ä»¬çš„æƒ³è±¡åŠ›åŠ ä¸€ç‚¹æç¤ºhintï¼Œä»è€Œæ›´å¥½çš„æ§åˆ¶generatorç”Ÿæˆçš„å†…å®¹ã€‚

Additionally, we can design a prompt encoding module to add a hint to our imagination, thereby better controlling the content generated by the generator.

ä»¥ä¸Šä¾¿æ˜¯æˆ‘å¯¹äºäººç±»å­¦ä¹ å’ŒAIå­¦ä¹ çš„ä¸€ç‚¹ç‚¹æ€è€ƒã€‚

The above is a little bit of my thinking about human learning and AI learning.

[ë²”ìš© ì¸ê³µ ì§€ëŠ¥ì˜ ë¯¸ë˜]AGENT AI: SURVEYING THE HORIZONS OF MULTIMODAL INTERACTION

On 25 Jan 2024, Stanford University, Microsoft Research, the University of California, Los Angeles and the University of Washington Co-published a surveying paper called: AGENT AI: SURVEYING THE HORIZONS OF MULTIMODAL INTERACTION

Abstract:

They try to draw the future of the Multi-modal AI systems. They present a new concept â€˜Agent AIâ€™, a promising avenue toward Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). (ë²”ìš© ì¸ê³µ ì§€ëŠ¥ì„ í–¥í•œ ìœ ë§í•œ ê¸¸ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.)

Agent AI system that can perceive and act in many different domains and applications, possibly serving as a route towards AGI using an agent paradigm(í‘œì¤€ ì–‘ì‹]). â€” Figure 1

How to use ubiquitous(ì–´ë””ì—ë‚˜ ìˆëŠ”) multi-modal AI systems?

Agents within physical and virtual environments(í˜„ì‹¤ ë° ê°€ìƒ í™˜ê²½ì˜ ì—ì´ì „íŠ¸) like the Jarvis in Iron Man(ì•„ì´ì–¸ë§¨ì˜ ìë¹„ìŠ¤ì²˜ëŸ¼).

Overview of an Agent AI system:

Data flow:

We define â€œAgent AIâ€ as a class of interactive systems that can

perceive visual stimuli, language inputs, and other environmentally-grounded data,

and can produce meaningful embodied actions.

We explore systems that aim to improve agents based on next-embodied action prediction by incorporating external knowledge, multi-sensory inputs, and human feedback.

mitigate(ê°ì†Œ) the hallucinations(í™˜ê°) of large foundation models and their tendency to generate environmentally incorrect outputs

We envision a future where people can easily create any
virtual reality or simulated scene and interact with agents embodied within the virtual environment. (like the OASIS game in the film â€œReady Player Oneâ€ ì˜í™” â€˜ë ˆë”” í”Œë ˆì´ì–´ ì›â€™ì˜ ì˜¤ì•„ì‹œìŠ¤ ê²Œì„ì²˜ëŸ¼ )

1. Introduction

1.1 Motivation

The AI community is on the cusp of a significant paradigm shift, transitioning from
creating AI models for passive, structured tasks to models capable of assuming dynamic, agentic roles in diverse and complex environments.

LLMs and VLMs â†’ a blend of linguistic proficiency, visual cognition, contextual memory, intuitive reasoning, and adaptability. ì–¸ì–´ ëŠ¥ë ¥, ì‹œê° ì¸ì§€, ë¬¸ë§¥ ê¸°ì–µ, ì§ê´€ì  ì¶”ë¡  ë° ì ì‘ë ¥. â†’ gaming, robotics, and healthcare domains. ê²Œì„, ë¡œë´‡ ê³µí•™ ë° ì˜ë£Œ ì˜ì—­ â†’ redefine human experiences and elevate the operational standard. ì¸ê°„ì˜ ê²½í—˜ì„ ì¬ì •ë¦½í•˜ê³  ì—…ë¬´ ìš´ìš© ìˆ˜ì¤€ì„ ë†’ì„. â†’ transformative impacts on industries and socio-economic ì‚°ì—…ê³¼ ì‚¬íšŒê²½ì œì— ëŒ€í•œ í˜ì‹  ì˜í–¥

1.2 Background

Large Foundation Models: can potentially tackle complex tasks

mathematical reasoning, professional law, generate complex plans for robots and game AI

ìˆ˜í•™ ë¬¸ì œ, ë²•í•™ ë¬¸ì œ, ê³„íš ì„¸ìš°ê¸° ë“±ë“±â€¦.

generate Python code â†’ execute these code in low-level controller

Interactive Learning:

  1. Feedback-based learning The AI adapts its responses based on direct user feedback.
  2. Observational Learning: The AI observes user interactions and learns implicitly.

2. Agent AI Integration

Previous technology and future challenge

2.1 [Previous technology] Infinite AI agent

AI agent systemsâ€™ abilities:

  1. Predictive Modeling
  2. Decision Making
  3. Handling Ambiguity
  4. Continuous Improvement [Infinite AI agent] 2D/3D embodied generation and editing interaction RoboGen: autonomously runs the cycles of task proposition, environment generation, and skill learning. https://robogen-ai.github.io/videos/pipeline_cropped.mp4

2.2 [Challenge] Agent AI with Large Foundation Models

2.2.1 Hallucinations(Fake answer)(í™˜ê°)

2.2.2 Biases and Inclusivity(í¸ê²¬ê³¼ í¬ìš©ì„±)

Training Data / Historical and Cultural Biases / Language and Context Limitations / Policies and Guidelines / Overgeneralization / Constant Monitoring and Updating / Amplification of Dominant Views / Ethical and Inclusive Design / User Guidelines

í•™ìŠµ ë°ì´í„° / ì—­ì‚¬ ë° ë¬¸í™”ì  í¸ê²¬ / ì–¸ì–´ ë° ë¬¸ë§¥ì˜ í•œê³„ / ì •ì±… ë° ê°€ì´ë“œë¼ì¸ / ì§€ë‚˜ì¹œ ì¼ë°˜í™” / ì§€ì†ì ì¸ ëª¨ë‹ˆí„°ë§ ë° ì—…ë°ì´íŠ¸ / ì§€ë°°ì ì¸ ê²¬í•´ì˜ í™•ëŒ€ / ìœ¤ë¦¬ì  ë° í¬ìš©ì  ë””ìì¸ / ì‚¬ìš©ì ê°€ì´ë“œë¼ì¸

2.2.4 Interpretability and Explainability

Imitation Learning â†’ Decoupling ëª¨ë°© í•™ìŠµ â†’ ë””ì»¤í”Œë§

2.2.6 Regulation

2.3 [Challenge] Agent AI for Emergent Abilities[ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ëŠ¥ë ¥]

Current modeling practices require developers to prepare large datasets for each domain to finetune/pretrain models; however, this process is costly and even impossible if the domain is new.

â­Unseen environments or scenarios?

The new emergent mechanism â€” Mixed Reality with Knowledge Inference Interaction

Enables the exploration of unseen environments for adaptation to virtual reality.

  1. Environment and Perception with task-planning and skill observation;
  2. Agent learning;
  3. Memory;
  4. Agent action;
  5. Cognition.

3 Agent AI Paradigm

We seek to accomplish several goals with our proposed framework:

  • Make use of existing pre-trained models and pre-training strategies to effectively bootstrap our agents with an effective understanding of important modalities, such as text or visual inputs.
  • Support for sufficient long-term task-planning capabilities.
  • Incorporate a framework for memory that allows for learned knowledge to be encoded and retrieved later.
  • Allow for environmental feedback to be used to effectively train the agent to learn which actions to take.

entry.title: label-studio-ml-backend's segment_anything_model example bug fix: previous annotation disappearing after making new one
entry.content:
Problem

When I try to use Interactive Annotation in Label Studio with Segment Anything Model Commits version: b2c31d3. I meet a problem, previous annotation is disappeared after making new annotation.(Latest version is fixed this problem[link])

Fix

To fix this problem, we need to modify the label-studio-ml-backend/label_studio_ml/examples/segment_anything_model/segment_anything_model.py file.
change the method to generate result id.

to
